intro: Eriogonum atrorubens, commonly known as the black-red buckwheat, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Polygonaceae family and is characterized by its upright growth habit and clusters of small, showy flowers. The plant typically blooms in late summer, producing pink to reddish flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are simple, alternate, and often have a hairy texture, while its stems are woody and branched. Eriogonum atrorubens is adapted to arid and rocky habitats, making it a resilient species in dry environments.
